greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows: T(n,k) is the number of Dyck paths of semilength n such that the area between the x-axis and the path is k (n>=0; 0<=k<=n^2).
comment: Row sums are the Catalan numbers (A000108).
Sums along falling diagonals give A005169. - _Joerg Arndt_, Mar 29 2014
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 0..32, flattened
example: T(4,10) = 3 because we have UDUUUDDD, UUUDDDUD and UUDUDUDD.
maple: G:=1/(1-t*z*g[1]): for i from 1 to 11 do g[i]:=1/(1-t^(2*i+1)*z*g[i+1]) od: g[12]:=0: Gser:=simplify(series(G,z=0,11)): for n from 0 to 7 do P[n]:=sort(coeff(Gser,z,n)) od: for n from 0 to 7 do seq(coeff(P[n],t,j),j=0..n^2) od; # yields sequence in triangular form
b:= proc(x, y) option remember; `if`(y<0 or y>x, 0, `if`(x=0, 1,
T:= n-> (p-> seq(coeff(p, z, i), i=0..degree(p)))(b(2*n, 0)):
mathematica: b[x_, y_] := b[x, y] = If[y<0 || y>x, 0, If[x==0, 1, Expand[b[x-1, y-1]*z^(y-1/2) + b[x-1, y+1]*z^(y+1/2)]]]; T[n_] := Function[{p}, Table[Coefficient[p, z, i], {i, 0, Exponent[p, z]}]][b[2*n, 0]]; Table[T[n], {n, 0, 10}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Mar 24 2015, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
results.author: _Emeric Deutsch_, Apr 08 2007
